quotes: During the first Barroso Commission, starting in November 2004, he was the European Commissioner for Energy.
Earlier in his career, while Latvia was still part of the Soviet Union, Andris Piebalgs worked as a teacher and was the Headmaster of the 1st Secondary School of Valmiera (1980-1990).
Supporters of Latvian self-determination gained victory in the elections of the Latvian Parliament on 18 March 1990.
On 7 May 1990, Andris Piebalgs was appointed as Minister of Education in the new Government,
one year later, in August 1991, Latvia regained full independence.
In 1993, Andris Piebalgs won a seat in the Latvian Parliament,
He served as the Chairman of the Budget and Finance Committee until 1994.

organizations.name: European Commission
quotes: Andris Piebalgs is an experienced Latvian politician who occupied key positions in both national and European political fields. During the first Barroso Commission, starting in November 2004, he was the European Commissioner for Energy.

organizations.name: The Economist magazine
quotes: In recognition of his leadership in European energy policy, The Economist magazine honoured him with the title 'Eurocrat of the Year' in 2007.

organizations.name: Regional Chamber of Commerce in Katowice (Poland)
quotes: In 2009, Andris Piebalgs received the 'Diamond Prize' from the Regional Chamber of Commerce in Katowice (Poland) for his work in developing a cohesive European Energy Policy for the further generations.

organizations.name: Energy Efficiency Global Forum
quotes: In 2009, the Energy Efficiency Global Forum presented him the Energy Efficiency Visionary Awards for his 'outstanding contributions to the advancement of energy efficiency'.

organizations.name: Ministry of Education in Latvia
quotes: He also served as Director of the Department in the Ministry of Education in Latvia.

organizations.name: Latvian People's Front
quotes: In 1988, Latvian People's Front, an organisation that united more than 200 000 people, was established.

Andris Piebalgs is an experienced Latvian politician who occupied key positions in both national and European political fields.
Earlier in his career, while Latvia was still part of the Soviet Union, Andris Piebalgs worked as a teacher and was the Headmaster of the 1st Secondary School of Valmiera (1980-1990).

In 2009, Andris Piebalgs received the 'Diamond Prize' from the Regional Chamber of Commerce in Katowice (Poland) for his work in developing a cohesive European Energy Policy for the further generations.
